column4: in those situations I boot off a livecd like sysresccd.org and just mount my drives and copy them over the network to somewhere else
good idea
instead of attempting any data rescue from the borked system
do you know?
I don't see why not. as long as you make detailed notes of what disk / partition ubuntu is on
or can i somehow repair the old one?
when it gets to the partition segment of the install, you'd need to do an advanced install
whats the symptom you're having?
ubuntu 11.10
what symptom are you seeing that you want remedied ?
whats the message on startup that indicates failure?
until i press the powerbutton
then it writes more stuff
have you tried modifying the grub boot line to turn acpi=off ?
when did this start happening?
i had screen problems (hardware) and rebooted some times to figure out what was wrong and suddently it came this
now i got a new display
hmm its difficult to diagnose when you can't get online and access logs to paste etc
is your windows 7 install on the same drive?
moment im uploading image of screen
yes
ok this is the screen: http://imagebin.org/193078
looking
in the other side of the screen it says ok
and this is 11.10 ? or 11.04
do you know what could be wrong?
it just hangs there
I see that /dev/sdb fails to mount, whats on that drive?
hmm it might be my external HDD. ill try to remove it and reboot
forums and various bug reports say that gnome-power-manager will hang on disks with insufficient space
if its got nothing from the OS perspective on it, then its probably fine
just didn't know if you put some ubuntu partitions on it
there should be plenty of space on the main disk
if ~Â 300GB is ok at least
getting you another picture
I believe you, you don't need to take a pic :)  I'm just reading through some bug reports and threads
when it boots like that, can you do ctrl-atl-f2 and get to another console where you can login to shell ?
some people suggest re-installing gnome-power manager
here i have booted without the disk connected: it looks slightly different: http://imagebin.org/193080
try the last solution on this page: http://superuser.com/questions/303343/ubuntu-11-04-hangs-at-checking-battery-state-while-booting
the one where he switches to a console, and runs startx manually
its probably not power related at all, thats just the last successful message before X fails to load
brb
it would make a lot of sense if it was due to graphic drivers
yeah, its probably trying to use your old monitor config for the new one and its different vertical and horiz sync
if startx doesn't work try X -configure
it says number of created screens does not match number of detected devices. Configuration failed
hmm ok one sec
ohh it also says failed to load module "vmwgfx" (module does not exist)
I haven't been keeping up with xorg changes and it looks like they modularized the config, I'm searching around for the best way to reconfigure. thats probably it.
heh ok and below it says please ignore the above warnings about not being able to load module/driver wmwgfx
I've reached my limit of knowledge on Xorg config issues, unless you can find someone who can direct you on reconfiguring it to support your new monitor, I'd say try a re-install
maybe i need to reinstall nvidia drivers?
I would just go back to generic ubuntu drivers to start
its the same monitor...just a new version...he just changed the broken display to another that works
if you can. that'll at least get you to a working X session
maybe if i remove old nvidia drivers first?
so did this happen after the monitor fix or the system upgrade?
can't hurt to try
no. before
it happened after the display broke but before the fix
how do i remove nvidia drivers from a terminal?
if they were installed via package system, you could use apt-get --purge remove <package-name>
but the X config is still going to reference them
i removed it
and now the screen is just black when i restart
ctrl-alt-f1 and try X -configure again
ctrl+alt+f1 dont work :(
do you think it would be difficult to just remove the entire old ubuntu installation and replace it with a new?
no, I think you can do it pretty easily via the installer
when you go to install it'll show you what partitions you've got and ask which you want to use
so you could just pick your existing ubuntu partition and tell it to use that and wipe it out
ill do that instead
I gotta run to a meeting, I'll be back in about an hour.
are you still there?
any luck?
hey....i have booted on a new live disk and now im trying to install a new ubuntu alongside windows and my old ubuntu
i figured it would be safer this way and then try to delete the old ubuntu after
ah gotcha. then if the new one works you can just delete the old and resize
yes exatly. Now i am waiting for the new ubuntu install program to finish its partition resizing...hoping that nothing goes wrong
the fragile part is the windows installation....i would really like to keep this one since the kids sometimes use if for their videogames
if you ever have to completely wipe, maybe consider windows inside a vm using kvm or virtualbox
yeah...but i dont know how well games perform in a vbox
that way if you ever have to re-image ubuntu, you can just copy the virtual disk image of windows somewhere else and then re-install your box and re-import it
yeah, you have to have enough resources. but I know virtualbox supports opengl direct3d etc
the new ubuntu installation works fine
i think ill just forget about the old for now...
awesome :)
gawd...now back to try and figuring out how to install gitorious
you can always use something like gparted to remove the old ubuntu install and resize the partitions (do it from a livecd or something)
yeah...but i was just worried about where the grub loader was located...i wouldnt wanna delete that one
ah yeah
I know aptitude will help you do things like remove unused packages (ie. you installed something that needed a bunch of deps but then uninstalled it)
but is there a difference between apt-get install and aptitude install ?
I think the only difference is how each tool analyzes the metadata about the package its installing
I think aptitude is more flexible / diverse in that way
